title: Financials Up as Treasury Yields Continue Rebound — Financials Roundup
text:
Shares of banks and other financial institutions rose sharply as Treasury yields continued a rebound from record lows.

Renewed hope that China and the U.S. will sign a truce in the trade battle and that the United Kingdom can avert a "hard Brexit" have prompted a pause in the recent Treasury rally.

Speaking in Ireland after a meeting with Irish counterpart Leo Varadkar, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson stuck to his pledge that the U.K. would leave the European Union on Oct. 31, despite parliamentary efforts to block that drastic move.

Strategists at one fund firm warned that investors in equities worldwide are currently underestimating the impact of a messy exit for the United Kingdom from the common market. "A lot of contingency planning - including by the financial service sector - has been put in place and could potentially mitigate the impact of any no-deal Brexit," said strategists for money manager BlackRock's Investment Institute. "Yet the exit of an EU member would be unprecedented, making it a significant risk with uncertain outcomes."

Shares of Irish largest lenders Allied Irish Banks and Bank of Ireland rebounded last week after the parliamentary maneuvers but remain deep in the red for the year because of hard Brexit fears.
